summary: First Edition: A novella writing website for grade 4 students with story-themed design, featuring multiple tabs (About, Writing Prompts, Image Creation, Character Development, Preview, Grammar Check, Writer's Block), word count, dark mode, save/load progress, PDF export, dictionary, thesaurus, and AI-powered writing suggestions
architectural_notes: Local storage for save/load progress (no backend required)
Story-themed UI design with child-friendly aesthetics
known_issues: Email submission not available on current plan - using local save/PDF download instead
Word count limit incorrectly enforcing 9 words instead of 2000 words
Live version still enforcing 9-word limit despite code fixes (deployment sync issue)

existing_features.title: Create an About page that explains First Edition is a novella writing platform for grade 4 students, describing its features and purpose in age-appropriate language
Create a Writing Prompts page that displays creative story prompts suitable for grade 4 students to inspire their novella writing
Create an Image Creation Tool page that generates multiple illustrations based on the story text written by the student, allowing them to create visuals for their novella
Create a Character Development page that helps students build and track their story characters with fields for names, descriptions, traits, and relationships
Create a Preview page that displays the student's novella in a formatted reading view, showing text and selected images together as a complete story
Create a Grammar Check page that analyzes the student's writing and displays grammar corrections with clear explanations suitable for grade 4 comprehension
Create a Writer's Block page that provides AI-generated writing suggestions based on what the student has written so far, helping them continue their story when stuck
Implement a main writing interface with a real-time word count tracker that updates as the student types their novella
Implement dark mode toggle that allows students to switch between light and dark themes across the entire application
Implement save progress functionality that stores the student's novella text, characters, selected images, and all project data in browser local storage
Implement PDF export functionality that allows students to download their complete novella as a PDF file, including text and images in a formatted layout
Integrate dictionary functionality that allows students to look up word definitions while writing their novella
Integrate thesaurus functionality that allows students to find synonyms and alternative words while writing their novella
Design the entire website with a story-themed visual style that appeals to grade 4 children (ages 9-10), using playful, book-inspired elements, warm colors, and engaging illustrations
Reposition the thesaurus/synonyms lookup tool to display next to the dictionary tool in the writing interface sidebar, creating a horizontal layout with both tools side-by-side
Create a flipbook save feature that stores the complete novella (title, story text, and selected images) as a viewable flipbook on the website, accessible through a dedicated page or viewer component
Add a submit/save button or action that triggers the flipbook save functionality, replacing or augmenting the existing PDF export as the primary method for preserving completed novellas
Add a maximum word count limit of 2000 words to the main writing textarea on the WritingPage, preventing users from typing beyond this limit and displaying the count as 'X / 2000' format

Fix the WritingPage textarea word count validation logic to correctly enforce a 2000-word maximum limit instead of the current 9-word limit, ensuring users can type up to 2000 words before being prevented from entering more text

Fix the WritingPage textarea word count validation to correctly enforce a 2000-word maximum limit in the live production application, ensuring users can type up to 2000 words before being prevented from entering more text (currently limiting to 9 words)
Add a Google research area component to the WritingPage that allows students to search Google directly from the writing interface without leaving the page
Investigate and fix the production deployment issue causing the WritingPage textarea to enforce a 9-word limit instead of the intended 2000-word maximum limit
